questions.question: Which ions are produced in aqueous solution by an acid?
questions.explanation: Acids are substances that produce hydrogen ions (H⁺) when dissolved in water.

questions.question: Which ions are produced in aqueous solution by an alkali?
questions.explanation: Alkalis are bases that dissolve in water to produce hydroxide ions (OH⁻).

questions.question: What colour does Universal Indicator turn in a strongly acidic solution?
questions.explanation: Universal Indicator turns red in strongly acidic solutions, indicating a low pH (high H⁺ concentration).

questions.question: A solution has a higher concentration of H⁺ ions than OH⁻ ions. What can be said about its pH?
questions.explanation: If [H⁺] > [OH⁻], the solution is acidic and pH < 7. pH 7 is neutral, pH > 7 is alkaline.

questions.question: Which of the following describes a weak acid?
questions.explanation: Weak acids only partially dissociate into ions in water, while strong acids are fully ionised.

questions.question: Which of these reactions is typical of acids?
options: Reaction with metals to give salt and hydrogen
Reaction with acids to give salt and water
Reaction with ammonium salts to give ammonia
Reaction with alkalis to give salt and hydrogen
questions.explanation: Acids react with reactive metals (above hydrogen in reactivity series) to produce a salt and hydrogen gas.

questions.question: What is the ionic equation for neutralisation?
questions.explanation: Neutralisation between an acid and an alkali involves the reaction between hydrogen ions and hydroxide ions to form water.

questions.question: Why might a farmer add calcium hydroxide to soil?
questions.explanation: Calcium hydroxide (slaked lime) is a base added to acidic soils to neutralise excess acidity and raise the pH, improving crop growth conditions.

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic reaction of bases?
options: Reaction with acids to give salt and water
Reaction with metals to give hydrogen
Reaction with carbonates to give CO₂
Reaction with water to give an acid
questions.explanation: Bases react with acids to form a salt and water in a neutralisation reaction.

questions.question: Sulfur dioxide (SO₂) is classified as an acidic oxide. Why?
options: It reacts with acids to form salt and water
It reacts with water to form an acid (H₂SO₃)
It reacts with alkalis to form an acid
questions.explanation: Acidic oxides are usually oxides of non-metals that react with water to form acids. SO₂ + H₂O → H₂SO₃ (sulfurous acid).
